Award.AwardTitle: The National Solar Observatory's Annual Solar Physics Workshops of the American Astronomical Society
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator will provide travel support for undergraduate and graduate students to attend national and international solar physics meetings.

A key component of this community service project will be to help students attend the annual Solar Physics Division (SPD) meeting of the American Astronomical Society. About 4-5 students will be selected each year for the SPD meeting, based on an application and selection process administered by the SPD Studentship Committee. Remaining funds will allow other conference organizers to request support for students intending to participate in their targeted solar physics meetings. New Mexico State University, serving as the distributor of the awards, will host a website with the relevant reimbursement information and forms for all student attendees.

Involvement of talented students at meetings and workshops that present and discuss exciting discoveries in solar physics will benefit the research community and foster a stimulating environment for future recruitment and the development of research programs for young scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar physics is a vibrant, multidisciplinary scientific field with many exciting discoveries announced every year that lead to further understanding of our nearest star. Involvement of talented students and young professionals in this process of discovery benefits the scientific community and fosters an environment for future progress. For example, the National Solar Observatory is completing the world's largest solar telescope that will have a minimum 50-year lifetime, and the next generation of scientists utilizing that telescope are this generation's students. Supporting student participation in any way possible is a key to building a capable cohort of scientists.


To this end, the "The National Solar Observatory's Annual Solar Physics Workshops of the American Astronomical Society" project was designed to promote student attendance and participation in important meetings and conferences focused on solar physics. From June 2011 to June 2015, 61 travel awards were given to individual students. These awards were used for attendance to 13 conferences, where students presented both poster and oral presentations. The students were selected on a competive basis by a committee, and further funding was typically provided and matched by a student's adviser. The process was very efficient and the students were recognized on a website.


Students that received travel awards from this project are proving that this works. For example, Maria Weber got funding to attend the AAS Solar Physics Division meeting in 2011 in Las Cruces, NM while a young graduate student in Boulder, CO. She earned her PhD in 2014 and is now a research fellow at the University of Exeter in England.


Tom Schad was supported in 2012 when he was a student in Tucson, AZ. After obtaining his PhD last year he was hired as a critical staff scientist to support the operations of the new NSO telescope on Maui, HI mentioned earlier. He will be an important part of the future of that telescope. Finally, Lisa Upton applied for and received funding in 2013 for a "Living with a Star" workshop. A year later, she obtained her PhD from Vanderbilt University having completed their Bridge Program. She even co-authored an article in the well-known journal "Science." 

These are just a few examples of many highlighting the success that can be found from supporting students at the right time to participate at professional meetings.
